{{Other uses|Battle of Kaniv (disambiguation){{!}}Battle of Kaniv}} {{Infobox military conflict | conflict = Battle of Kaniów | partof = the [[Eastern Front (World War I)]] | image = [[File:Odznaka Zwiazku Kaniowczykow rewers mosiadz.jpg|220px]] | caption = Commemorative brass award awarded to Polish soldiers years after the battle. Text reads: "1918 - Kaniów - II Korpus". | date = 10–11 May 1918 | place = Near [[Kaniv]] (''Kaniów'') | coordinates = | territory = | result = German victory | status = | combatant1 = {{flag|Poland|size=25px}} [[Polish II Corps in Russia|Polish II Corps]] | combatant2 = {{flag|German Empire}} | commander1 = [[Józef Haller de Hallenburg]] | commander2 = Zierhold | strength1 = 8,000 | strength2 = 12,000 | casualties1 = 1,000 dead or wounded, 3,250 captured | casualties2 = 1,500 dead or wounded | notes = }} '''Battle of Kaniv''', or '''Battle of Kaniów''' took place during [[World War I]] on the night of 10–11 May 1918, near [[Kaniv]], [[Ukraine]] ({{lang-uk|Канів}}, Polish: Kaniów, ) between Polish and German army troops. The fighting pitted the [[Polish II Corps in Russia]] (including [[Brigade II of the Polish Legions]]), under general [[Józef Haller de Hallenburg]], against the [[German Imperial Army]] (including the [[28th German Landwehr Brigade|28th]] [[Landwehr]] Brigade), under general Zierhold. Ultimately the Germans were victorious with about half of the Polish forces surrendering and the rest retreating in disarray.<ref name="tucker"/>
==Background== On 15 February, protesting against the [[Treaty of Brest-Litovsk (February 9, 1918)|Treaty of Brest-Litovsk]] which reduced the chances for the creation of an independent Poland, the II Brigade of the Polish Legions, formerly part of the [[Austro-Hungarian Army]], [[Battle of Rarańcza|broke through the frontline near Rarańcza]] and merged with the Polish units formerly in the [[Imperial Russian Army|Russian Army]], joining the newly formed [[Polish II Corps in Russia]].<ref name=Woyno/> The Germans, however, saw the II Corps as troublesome, and decided to ensure it would be disarmed, or would otherwise be incapacitated.<ref name=Woyno/>
On 18 April the II Corps was ordered by the [[Regency Council]] to stop near [[Kaniv]] in [[Ukraine]]; in a triangle between Potik, [[Kozyn]] and Stepantsi.<ref name="Woyno"/> Soon it begun to be surrounded by a nearby German units.<ref name=Woyno/> On 6 May the commander of the [[28th German Landwehr Brigade]], General Zierhold, subordinate of Marshal [[Hermann von Eichhorn]], issued an ultimatum to the II Corps, demanding it lay down its arms and surrender.<ref name=Woyno/> II Corps readied for battle, and surprised Zierhold, who was unprepared for battle.<ref name=Woyno/> Zierhold backed down saying that the ultimatum was a miscommunication.<ref name=Woyno/> Soon however Zierhold received reinforcements, which convinced him he has enough strength to force the issue.<ref name=Woyno/>
==Battle== [[Image:Kaniów 1918.PNG|thumb|right|Map of the battle]]
On the night of the tenth of May to the eleventh of May 1918, II Corps was surrounded and attacked by German units.<ref name=Woyno/> Polish units, initially surprised, formed on the village of Yemchykha and took defensive positions.<ref name=Woyno/> The II Corps resisted for about a day, and both sides sustained heavy losses.<ref name=Woyno/> By the evening of 11 May the Germans, who did not expect the Poles to put such a stiff resistance, proposed a ceasefire and negotiations.<ref name=Woyno/> With supplies running low the Poles accepted the offer to negotiate, and eventually agreed to an honorable capitulation.<ref name=Woyno/>
==Aftermath== The battle resulted in heavy losses for the Germans, estimated at about 1,500 dead and 273 wounded.<ref name=Woyno/><ref name="Wrzosek1969"/> Polish losses are estimated to be much smaller, at about few dozen killed and about 150 wounded.<ref name="Kronika powstań polskich 1794-1944"/><ref name="Kresy wschodnie Rzeczypospolitej w obronie polskości"/> Half of the Polish survivors were arrested and sent to [[prisoner of war]] camps (number of prisoners is estimated at about 3,250;<ref name="Podhorodecki1997"/> another estimate suggests 4,000 imprisoned, and 1,500-2,000 who escaped<ref name="Wrzosek1969"/>), but the others managed to escape.<ref name=tucker/><ref name=Woyno/> Those who escaped included the Polish commander [[Józef Haller de Hallenburg]], who faked his death in the battle, and fled to [[France]] where he was later appointed commander of the new Polish unit, the [[Blue Army (Poland)|Blue Army]] (or Haller's Army).<ref name="tucker"/><ref name="google"/><ref name="google2"/> In the [[Second Polish Republic]], several units would adopt the name "of Kaniów" in honor of that battle: the 28th, 29th, 30th and 31st Infantry Regiments (of Kaniów Rifleman, Polish: ''Pułki Strzelców Kaniowskich") and 6th [[Uhlan]] Kaniów Regiment (''6 Pułk Ułanów Kaniowskich'').<ref name="Jarno2004"/><ref name="Hlawaty1973"/>
